text: What's nice about your story <@U016TGY3676> is that it sounds like you've enjoyed that journey and I imagine you've benefitted from the learning you've done along the way in other ways too. Perhaps the learning and enjoyment may even have been of greater benefit than the money? Either way - the point is that it doesn't sound like it's had a negative impact on your life. That has mostly been my experience too but not all the time. At times I've become too obsessed, worked too late and too long or set aside other things. I've never really lost money but when the cross matcher was introduced in running  in 2014 my take home income went from quite a lot to £30K and I really didn't know if I could turn it around. I know that's still a lot of money but even so I found it massively stressful and it was an insight into how it can feel if betting for profit isn't working out.

elements.text: What's nice about your story

is that it sounds like you've enjoyed that journey and I imagine you've benefitted from the learning you've done along the way in other ways too. Perhaps the learning and enjoyment may even have been of greater benefit than the money? Either way - the point is that it doesn't sound like it's had a negative impact on your life. That has mostly been my experience too but not all the time. At times I've become too obsessed, worked too late and too long or set aside other things. I've never really lost money but when the cross matcher was introduced in running  in 2014 my take home income went from quite a lot to £30K and I really didn't know if I could turn it around. I know that's still a lot of money but even so I found it massively stressful and it was an insight into how it can feel if betting for profit isn't working out.

text: We all know that gambling doesn't pay for the vast majority and that putting a layer of computing between yourself and the bets doesn't change that. So my biggest piece of advice to <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> and anyone else who isn't taking money home is to keep on asking yourself _"is this rewarding me somehow right now"_ and if the answer is _"no"_ then for god's sake and your own please please stop. Don't waste your time or your money on the hope that you'll benefit in the future from suffering now because that so rarely happens.

elements.text: We all know that gambling doesn't pay for the vast majority and that putting a layer of computing between yourself and the bets doesn't change that. So my biggest piece of advice to
and anyone else who isn't taking money home is to keep on asking yourself
"is this rewarding me somehow right now"
and if the answer is
"no"
then for god's sake and your own please please stop. Don't waste your time or your money on the hope that you'll benefit in the future from suffering now because that so rarely happens.

text: I would also advise anyone to put in place the criteria for when you stop in advance so that you don't have to make that decision when you get there. I've done that for myself since day 1: I keep a relatively modest float and never deposit so if I ever bust the float out I'm done. For someone else the criteria could be _"if I'm not profitable by New Year or total losses exceed £2000,"_  or whatever's appropriate. Hell - _"If I ever work past midnight or miss a family meal"_ would be excellent additions. Whatever - just please put in place some safeguards to protect yourself and your quality of life.

elements.text: I would also advise anyone to put in place the criteria for when you stop in advance so that you don't have to make that decision when you get there. or whatever's appropriate. Hell -
"If I ever work past midnight or miss a family meal"
would be excellent additions. Whatever - just please put in place some safeguards to protect yourself and your quality of life.

text: <@UGV299K6H> are you able elaborate on how much you did work at the start/middle? I know now that things tick along nicely so I imagine it's more maintenance or are you still exploring new ideas?

elements.text: are you able elaborate on how much you did work at the start/middle? I know now that things tick along nicely so I imagine it's more maintenance or are you still exploring new ideas?

text: I've always done sporadic intensive periods, usually a couple of months of working quite long hours then allowing data to accumulate for a few months whilst I do other things. These days I do very little for 3 or 4 months at a time then maybe a week or two of full time equivalent work unless I'm doing some big new thing in which case it can be longer. I haven't done a stroke of development or analysis in 2021 except to quickly write up a new idea I had and set it going with my customary £200. I haven't even downloaded my data or results for a couple of months.

elements.text: I've always done sporadic intensive periods, usually a couple of months of working quite long hours then allowing data to accumulate for a few months whilst I do other things. These days I do very little for 3 or 4 months at a time then maybe a week or two of full time equivalent work unless I'm doing some big new thing in which case it can be longer. I haven't done a stroke of development or analysis in 2021 except to quickly write up a new idea I had and set it going with my customary £200. I haven't even downloaded my data or results for a couple of months.

text: I do have some new ideas but not much incentive to develop them as my income is more than sufficient. If it dropped off I would work on it.

elements.text: I do have some new ideas but not much incentive to develop them as my income is more than sufficient. If it dropped off I would work on it.

text: Overall I think I've worked on it too much over the years and it's a bit of a regret that I've spent so much time on it. I could have done 20% of the work and got 80% of the reward.

elements.text: Overall I think I've worked on it too much over the years and it's a bit of a regret that I've spent so much time on it. I could have done 20% of the work and got 80% of the reward.

text: It's easy to over-do the analysis and under-do the waiting.

elements.text: It's easy to over-do the analysis and under-do the waiting.

text:
Interesting, I have naturally moved to 6 months on / 6 months off over the summer. Probably the wrong way round due to the number of races but I find I work better when the weather is poor. 

That isn’t to say I don’t do anything now but my motivation drops to zero for programming when the sun is shining. However this is very easy to do once up and running and during the early days 5-8am almost every day and every spare second at the weekend was my golden time.

text: <@UGV299K6H> Yes, I've probably had more enjoyment from the learning than the money. My current "real job" is building, coding and commissioning control panels for large industrial automation machines. I get a real sense of satisfaction when they're complete. The probability that learning to code for gambling led me into this side of my engineering career is...100%. So it's benefited my life in many other ways. Which is great, because I couldn't afford to live off my Betfair income. :joy:

elements.text: Yes, I've probably had more enjoyment from the learning than the money. My current "real job" is building, coding and commissioning control panels for large industrial automation machines. I get a real sense of satisfaction when they're complete. The probability that learning to code for gambling led me into this side of my engineering career is...100%. So it's benefited my life in many other ways. Which is great, because I couldn't afford to live off my Betfair income.

text: Oh that's really interesting what kind of machines?

elements.text: Oh that's really interesting what kind of machines?

text:
Currently doing a lot of work for a research company that build biodiesel reactors. Fascinating process. They basically squirt some scabby oil in one end and get diesel and glycerol out the other.
But we also build control for engine lubrication on ship engines, hydro power generator stations, and even some tiny panels for a guy in the unit  next door who sells filtration systems to the railway industry.

elements.text:
Currently doing a lot of work for a research company that build biodiesel reactors. Fascinating process. They basically squirt some scabby oil in one end and get diesel and glycerol out the other.
But we also build control for engine lubrication on ship engines, hydro power generator stations, and even some tiny panels for a guy in the unit  next door who sells filtration systems to the railway industry.

text: Awesome.

elements.text: Awesome.

text: Do you want a job? :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

elements.text: Do you want a job?

text: Oh God that word strikes fear into my heart.

elements.text: Oh God that word strikes fear into my heart.

text: <@U016TGY3676> why does the railway industry need filtration systems?

elements.text: why does the railway industry need filtration systems?

text: Engines and gearboxes. They're big ol' things with gallons of oil. The bloke next door to us has invented some fancy machine to recondition the oils without draining them. It basically recirculates the oil through some filters and back to the engines/gearboxes.

elements.text: Engines and gearboxes. They're big ol' things with gallons of oil. The bloke next door to us has invented some fancy machine to recondition the oils without draining them. It basically recirculates the oil through some filters and back to the engines/gearboxes.

text: Do they plug the train into it like dialysis or is it continuously circulating?

elements.text: Do they plug the train into it like dialysis or is it continuously circulating?

text: And what about ships? Can they do/do they need the same?

elements.text: And what about ships? Can they do/do they need the same?

text: Yeah, it's basically dialysis for trains. I think there's a limited number of times they can do it before the oil loses it's properties. Not sure about the ships, he only supplies the rail industry. Our involvement in ship lubrication is more about monitoring and safety cos ships are usually built around the engines, so replacement means cutting the side off. Our control panels basically keep the oil pumps running at all costs and shutdown the engines if something goes wrong. There are loads of HMI screens with levels, temperatures, flow rates, etc positioned all around the ship. I guess it's more of an early warning system.

elements.text: Yeah, it's basically dialysis for trains. I think there's a limited number of times they can do it before the oil loses it's properties. Not sure about the ships, he only supplies the rail industry. Our involvement in ship lubrication is more about monitoring and safety cos ships are usually built around the engines, so replacement means cutting the side off. Our control panels basically keep the oil pumps running at all costs and shutdown the engines if something goes wrong. There are loads of HMI screens with levels, temperatures, flow rates, etc positioned all around the ship. I guess it's more of an early warning system.

text: We also monitor vibration and bearing wear. Interesting stuff TBH.

elements.text: We also monitor vibration and bearing wear. Interesting stuff TBH.

text:
It was interesting reading <@U016TGY3676> story. I remember my dad having a bet each Saturday (5p Yankee!, 55p). At the time I had just started my first paper round at 12 and he would often ask me to stop by the bookies to put a bet on for him at 12!
Just on a side topic, my youngest son has obviously noticed me toiling away learning Python and just recently he said "I think Id like to learn that dad whilst I have the summer free" so Ive set him up pycharm and he has access to my Udemy course
Just an interesting contrast between what I had with my dad and him checking the 'form' and ringing the selection with his pen and how things are more high tech today :grinning: I often wonder what my dad would think if he knew how many bets I was doing each day

text: :grinning::grinning:

Idk how you guys keep at it continuously . After a bunch of big breakthroughs and having things work consistently for a while, I find I have to do nothing for many weeks before I start giving it my proper attention again (aside from the occasional monitoring and benchmarking). Maybe it's because the breakthroughs themselves consume a lot of energy and then you need to recharge, and can do so while things are working in the background. Agreed the sunshine is very distracting.
